IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: CONNECTICUT LANDMARKS INSPIRES INTEREST AND ENCOURAGES LEARNING ABOUT THE AMERICAN PAST BY PRESERVING SELECTED HISTORIC PROPERTIES, COLLECTIONS AND STORIES AND PRESENTING PROGRAMS THAT MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE THE PUBLIC AND OUR COMMUNITIES.
IRS990.MissionDesc: CONNECTICUT LANDMARKS INSPIRES INTEREST AND ENCOURAGES LEARNING ABOUT THE AMERICAN PAST BY PRESERVING SELECTED HISTORIC PROPERTIES, COLLECTIONS AND STORIES AND PRESENTING PROGRAMS THAT MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE THE PUBLIC AND OUR COMMUNITIES.
IRS990.Desc: CT LANDMARKS PRESENTS CONNECTICUT'S HERITAGE THROUGH MUSEUM VISITS, TOURS, LECTURES, PROGRAMS, CONFERENCES AND EVENTS AND UTILIZES ITS MUSEUM SITES AND COLLECTIONS TO PRESENT PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS CONTEMPORARY HUMAN CONCERNS.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: CTL PRESERVES ELEVEN IMPORTANT HISTORIC PROPERTIES ACROSS CONNECTICUT, NINE OF WHICH ARE OPEN AS MUSEUMS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: A WRITTEN POLICY IS BEING ADOPTED.
THERE WAS NO INCOME OR EXPENSE TO RECOGNIZE IN THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.

THE SOCIETY FOLLOWS THE REVENUE RECOGNITION TOPIC OF THE FASB CODIFICATION. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TOPIC, THE SOCIETY DOES NOT CAPITALIZE THE COST OR APPRAISAL VALUE OR THE COSTS OF RESTORATIONS AND RENOVATIONS OF ANY HISTORIC ASSETS/PROPERTIES OR RECOGNIZE THEM AS REVENUES OR GAINS. THESE ASSETS/PROPERTIES, WHICH ARE SIGNIFICANT IN VALUE, HAVE BEEN ACQUIRED BY THE SOCIETY FROM BEQUESTS AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESTORED. THE TOPIC PROVIDES THAT SUCH DONATIONS NEED NOT BE RECOGNIZED IF THEY ARE ADDED TO COLLECTIONS THAT ARE HELD FOR PUBLIC EXHIBITION, EDUCATION, OR RESEARCH IN FURTHERANCE OF PUBLIC SERVICE RATHER THAN FINANCIAL GAIN; ARE PROTECTED, KEPT UNENCUMBERED, CARED FOR, AND PRESERVED.

CONNECTICUT LANDMARKS (CTL) PRESERVES AND INTERPRETS FOUR CENTURIES OF DOMESTIC ARCHITECTURE AND FAMILY LIFE THROUGH ITS NINE HISTORIC HOUSE MUSEUMS. CTL'S MISSION IS TO INSPIRE INTEREST AND ENCOURAGE LEARNING ABOUT THE AMERICAN PAST BY PRESERVING SELECTED HISTORIC PROPERTIES, COLLECTIONS AND STORIES AND PRESENTING PROGRAMS THAT MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE THE PUBLIC AND OUR COMMUNITIES. LOCATED THROUGHOUT CONNECTICUT, THE MUSEUMS DISPLAY APPROXIMATELY 7,500 OBJECTS, WITH ANOTHER 2,000 ARTIFACTS IN STORAGE. THE ARTIFACTS ARE PRIMARILY FURNITURE, BUT ALSO INCLUDE METALS, CERAMICS, GLASSWARE, WORKS OF ART ON PAPER, TEXTILES AND PAINTINGS. OVER 400 LINEAR FEET OF ARCHIVAL MATERIALS ARE ALSO STORED IN THE ARCHIVES, INCLUDING LETTERS, DIARIES, BUSINESS PAPERS, PHOTOGRAPHS AND GLASS PLATE NEGATIVES. FOUR PROPERTIES WERE BEQUEATHED TO CTL WITH EXTENSIVE FAMILY COLLECTIONS. THE BUTLER-MCCOOK HOUSE & GARDEN IN HARTFORD WAS HOME TO FOUR GENERATIONS OF ONE FAMILY, FROM 1782 UNTIL 1971. ORIGINAL FURNISHINGS RANGE FROM 18TH-CENTURY HARTFORD FURNITURE TO VICTORIAN-ERA TOYS, FINE 19TH-CENTURY PAINTINGS AND JAPANESE SAMURAI ARMOUR. THE ISHAM-TERRY HOUSE IS A TIME CAPSULE OF GENTEEL LIFE IN TURN-OF-THE CENTURY HARTFORD. THE 1854 ITALIANATE VILLA, OCCUPIED BY THE ISHAMS FROM 1896 UNTIL THE 1970S, IS FILLED WITH OBJECTS OF HISTORICAL AND FAMILY SIGNIFICANCE: RARE BOOKS, CONNECTICUT-MADE CLOCKS, MEMORABILIA FROM HARTFORD HIGH SCHOOL, AND SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS AND MEDICINES FROM DR. ISHAM'S OFFICE. THE BELLAMY-FERRIDAY HOUSE, BUILT IN 1754 FOR BETHLEHEM MINISTER JOSEPH BELLAMY, A RENOWNED LEADER OF THE GREAT AWAKENING, FEATURES THE COLLECTION OF CAROLINE FERRIDAY, THE LAST OCCUPANT OF THE HOUSE. ACQUIRED BY HER FAMILY IN 1912, MS. FERRIDAY RESTORED AND FURNISHED THE HOUSE WITH LITCHFIELD COUNTY ANTIQUES. THE FEDERAL-STYLE AMASA DAY HOUSE, BUILT IN 1816 IN MOODUS, IS FURNISHED LARGELY WITH OBJECTS OWNED BY MEMBERS OF THE DAY FAMILY, INCLUDING TOYS AND LOCALLY PRODUCED CERAMICS AND SILVER. THE ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS INCLUDE PHOTOGRAPHS AND GLASS PLATE NEGATIVES TAKEN BY PIONEERING ART PHOTOGRAPHER, AMASA DAY CHAFEE. THE 1678 JOSHUA HEMPSTED HOUSE IS ONE OF NEW ENGLAND'S OLDEST AND BEST-DOCUMENTED DWELLINGS. A RARE STONE DWELLING BUILT IN 1759 BY NATHANIEL HEMPSTED, GRANDSON OF JOSHUA, IS LOCATED ON THE SAME PROPERTY IN NEW LONDON. BOTH HOUSES FEATURE 17TH AND 18TH-CENTURY FURNITURE, CERAMICS, PEWTER, FIREPLACE EQUIPMENT AND AN EXTENSIVE COLLECTION OF TEXTILE MAKING EQUIPMENT. THE BUTTOLPH-WILLIAMS HOUSE, BUILT C. 1711 IN WETHERSFIELD, REFLECTS THE CONTINUING POPULARITY OF TRADITIONAL ARCHITECTURE IN CONNECTICUT. AN ARRAY OF 17TH AND 18TH-CENTURY FURNISHINGS IS ON DISPLAY, INCLUDING A KITCHEN FILLED WITH A REMARKABLE ASSORTMENT OF COLONIAL-ERA COOKING IMPLEMENTS. THE PHELPS-HATHEWAY HOUSE (1761) IN SUFFIELD WAS PURCHASED BY WEALTHY LAND SPECULATOR OLIVER PHELPS IN 1788. PHELPS ADDED AN ELABORATE HIGH-STYLE ADDITION IN 1795. THIS ADDITION, ON WHICH NOTED AMERICAN ARCHITECT ASHER BENJAMIN WORKED, CONTAINS THE LARGEST ASSEMBLAGE OF ORIGINAL 18TH-CENTURY FRENCH WALLPAPER IN SITU IN THE COUNTRY. THE HOUSE IS FURNISHED WITH OUTSTANDING 18TH-CENTURY CONNECTICUT FURNITURE, INCLUDING SEVERAL PIECES ATTRIBUTED TO CABINETMAKER ELIPHALET CHAPIN. THE HALE HOMESTEAD, BUILT IN 1776, BELONGED TO THE PARENTS AND FAMILY OF CONNECTICUT'S STATE HERO, NATHAN HALE. THE COLONIAL INTERIOR FEATURES 18TH-CENTURY CONNECTICUT FURNITURE AND ACCESSORIES, INCLUDING NATHAN HALE'S TRUNK, HIS BROTHER, JOHN HALE'S DESK AND BOOKCASE, AND OTHER PERIOD APPROPRIATE ARTIFACTS.
THE SOCIETY RECEIVES MONTHLY DISTRIBUTIONS BASED ON THE ENDOWMENT SPENDING POLICY. ANY OTHER DISTRIBUTIONS WOULD BE USED FOR SPECIAL CAPITAL PROJECTS OR MAJOR MAINTENANCE TO ANY OF THE HOMES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11B
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: A COPY OF FORM 990 WAS PROVIDED TO EVERY MEMBER OF CT LANDMARKS GOVERNING BODY.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 12C
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY IS REVIEWED, SIGNED AND MONITORED ANNUALLY.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BOARD OF TRUSTEE GATHERS AND REVIEWS COMPARABILITY DATA.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION MAKES ITS GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.
THE SELECTION PROCESS OF THE INDEPENDENT AUDITOR HAS NOT CHANGED FROM THE PRIOR YEAR.
